summary: This is a memorandum from the Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) to the Assistant Inspector General for the Investigations Division, responding to the OIG's draft report on the investigation into BOP's custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The BOP concurs with all eight recommendations aimed at improving policies related to suicide watch, inmate monitoring, staffing, and security procedures following Epstein's death.

keyFacts: The Office of the Inspector General (OIG) conducted an investigation and review of the Federal Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.
The BOP concurs with all eight recommendations from the OIG draft report, which focus on improving procedures for suicide watch, inmate monitoring, staffing, and security camera systems.

The report states that the misconduct described involved a failure to follow BOP policies by a few employees at MCC New York, representing a very small percentage of the approximately 35,000 BOP employees.

The BOP acknowledges that in the years since Epstein's death, it has updated its process related to suicide watch and psychological observation, including having psychologists make individualized care recommendations.
The document is a formal response from the BOP Director to the OIG, dated June 22, 2023, regarding the draft report on the Epstein incident.
